awd_abstract_narration:
The multi-year project will study 50 flipped, hybrid, and online courses offered in the three major STEM Schools at the University of California, Irvine (UCI). Higher education institutions are increasing the number of courses they offer that use elements of virtual instruction in the belief that these courses will lead to better learning, lower costs, greater access, and higher graduation rates. However, recent meta-analyses of virtual learning in higher education all conclude that there is a dearth of rigorous research on the topic.  The study will assist higher education administrators, instructors, and course designers to make effective decisions in planning the kinds of virtual learning environments that can best meet the needs of undergraduate STEM students, especially in the vital first two years of college. A major focus of the study will be the impact of virtual learning environments on underrepresented minorities, first-generation college students, students of low-socioeconomic status backgrounds, and women.  The research will provide some of the best evidence to date about the impact of higher education virtual environments on learning outcomes, attitudes toward STEM, and persistence in STEM majors.

The proposed project will include 50 separate studies of STEM instruction at UCI. The majority will employ random assignment of students to investigate the comparative impacts of virtual vs. traditional learning with the same instructor. Experimental and quasi-experimental techniques will be used to compare the impact of virtual courses compared to traditional courses taught by the same instructor on students? attitudes toward STEM study, learning outcomes, and success and persistence in future STEM courses. Quantitative and qualitative indicators of instructional practices and student performance and engagement will be collected to compare and describe practices across course formats and then distilled into recommended best practices. Statistical data mining techniques, including sequence modeling, clustering, text mining, matrix factorization, and high-dimensional predictive modeling will be used on a rich set of institutional data, self-reported survey data, engagement data (logins, video watching, participation in online forums), and outcome data to extract and analyze information about student learning behaviors and their relationship to learning outcomes. The instruments and designs used in the study, including observation protocols, surveys, interview protocols, and cutting-edge methodological approaches, will allow future researchers to replicate and build on these analyses, thereby contributing to the broader understanding of virtual learning environments.  The project, supported through the EHR Core Research (ECR) program of fundamental research in STEM, will contribute important research findings regarding STEM learning, learning environments, and broadening participation in STEM, which are important priorities of the ECR program.

Project Outcomes: Investigating Virtual Learning Environments

The goal of this 5-year project was to understand the impact of online STEM courses on college student learning and achievement, with most of the work occurring prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. These included fully online, flipped, and hybrid courses. Our work primarily focused on relating institutional and instructional practices to achievement, persistence, and success in online courses. We also examined the role of motivation and self-regulation on learning and achievement while additionally considering how traditionally underrepresented in STEM (e.g., first-generation, low-income, underrepresented minority) uniquely navigated online learning. Our main findings and accomplishments were as follows.

Institution-Wide Comparisons

In two campus-wide studies of more than 30,000 students in hundreds of STEM courses, we  found that students’ grades were slightly lower in online courses compared to face-to-face courses, but at-risk students (low-income students, first-generation students, low-performing students) were not found to suffer additional course performance penalties of online course participation. We also found that offering more online courses in a particular major led to higher likelihood of successful four-year graduation and overall faster time to degree for students in that major.

We also addressed the question as to which sources of data are most predictive of student success. Using data from 2,000 college students, we examined the utility of institutional data, clickstream data, and survey data for accurately and fairly predicting short-term and long-term student performance. We found that institutional data and clickstream data both had decent predictive power, but survey data showed very little predictive utility. Combining institutional data with clickstream data led to even higher accuracy than using either alone.

Student Motivation

When examining students' reasons for enrolling in an online versus face-to-face section of the same STEM course, we found very different motivations among students. Students most frequently cited learning advantages for enrolling in face-to-face courses (e.g., more regular contact with instructor or students) while citing life constraints for enrolling in face-to-face courses (e.g, need to work or care for a dependent). Students who chose online instruction for these reasons tended to perform worse than their face-to-face peers.

Self-Regulated Learning

Using clickstream data obtained from the university’s learning management system, our project developed new machine learning models of self-regulated learning to parse out nuances in how procrastination related to academic outcomes in online STEM courses.  A number of our studies found that early planning behaviors are especially important for course success—they consistently predicted higher final course grades, even after controlling for important demographic variables. Interestingly, first-generation college students classified as early planners achieved at similar levels as their non-first-generation peers. In addition to increasing our knowledge about self-regulated learning and first-generation achievement, this body of work has led to developing reliable clickstream measures of self-regulated learning.

Training and Dissemination

We have published more than 30 papers and presented our findings to educational leaders and practitioners at higher education conferences. We have helped create the Digital Learning Institute at UCI which has shared our findings to scores of UCI instructors. We have distilled our findings into an Online Learning Research Center website, which became an important source of knowledge and resources during the COVID-19 pandemic for both college and K-12 teachers in the US and around the world; the website was also translated and reproduced in German, further extending its reach.

Finally, we have developed formal training for graduate students on working with clickstream data, and have developed resources on accessing clickstream and learning analytic data from Canvas, a popular learning management system. Because many learning institutions use Canvas, we have worked on formalizing our training materials and tools and have made them publically available. Our activities on the project also helped pave the way for a new grant we have received from the Institute of Education Sciences to train diverse undergraduates in learning analytics and educational data science to reduce inequities in these fields.
